project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Hi,

I recently upgraded to version 4.4 and I see that double click is no more possible on cards. 
In previous version, when I was in view "list", I was able to double click on the issue to have more details about it (and optionnaly edit fields). 

In this new version, it's not possible, I have to switch to "Summary" or "Cards" to do that. 

I really liked this feature. Was it removed intentionnaly ? Is it possible to add it again ?
fields.summary: Switch to summary or card view with a double click

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Hi,

I've upgraded from version 3 to version 4 recently. I like to have the ability to edit the issue on the planning board or the task board. However, I don't like to fall automatically in edit mode when I click on the summary.

I am maybe stressed, but I click all the time on the screen to select issues or look over a text.
It's really frustrating to open the "Edit mode" on the summary each time I click on it. I have to click on the cross to close the "Edit mode" and that's not really usefull.


In my humble opinion, the "Edit mode" should be enabled only with the "pen" icon or with a double click.

What do you think ?
fields.summary: Enable line editing on double click or with the "pen" icon

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As per the attached screen shot, if you have a project with a "short name" that is more than a few characters, issue IDs don't display in the title area of cards on the planning board. Instead they are displayed over the top of the content of the card.

I think this only applies to summary view (unless you have hugely long "short" names for projects) because otherwise the cards are bigger.

Take a look at the screen capture to understand what I mean a bit better.
fields.summary: Long issue IDs do not display inside the card title area

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We use filter criteria quite a bit, as we have many teams sharing the same projects (due to other limitations in how JIRA works).

With GreenHopper 5.0, it looks like we are going to lose the one click Filter "Edit" functionality?

If I click the filter icon from the planning view, I see only three checkboxes:

* [ ] Only my issues.
* [ ] Hide sub-tasks.
* [ ] Only pending issues.

It looks like the new workflow is to click on the down arrow next to the context "On the Fly", click "Manage", click "Filter". This is more effort for something we routinely do, and I think our users might have trouble finding the function.

We really liked it when GreenHopper introduced this functionality (one click to the filter editor when the context menu was pulled up) back in GreenHopper 4.1 or so, and I am concerned that our users will not appreciate us deploying GreenHopper 5.0 due to this lost functionality.

Can you please add this functionality back in some way? Even adding it to the right of the three checkboxes that the filter icon pulls up might be ok?
fields.summary: Restore one click Filter "Edit" functionality to GreenHopper 5.0.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The white cards are pretty but less functional.  On practically every physical wallboard I have seen we always used colored cards.  Now we see a sea of white cards and we need to look explicitly for the color tab which is a bit confusing and frankly less much less clear than Jira used to be. e.g. if I am scanning issues in outline form, I need to constantly look to the left hand side of parent issues to see if the parent is a bug.story, etc.  It is also much harder at a glance to see if we have a bunch of tasks or bugs left in a sprint.

Please at least make it an option to allow us to have full colored cards like we used to have and loved.
fields.summary: In GH 5.0 no longer any way to color the entire card

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We are using Greenhopper for some business planning processes and wanted to use the Flagged field, just not the 'Impediment' value.

I created a custom field context for the Flagged field (for all issue types in that project), but Greenhopper never seemed to recognize it and only pulled the default value.

I would have expected greenhopper to have picked up the custom context and have that as the option.
fields.summary: 'Flagged' configuration ignores custom field contexts

fields.summary: Switch to summary or card view with a double click

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
JIRA 4.x really improved our experience by reducing the set of JIRA projects to the list of JIRA projects that a particular user regularly accesses. Unfortunately, GreenHopper stills lists *all* projects (or all projects that have GreenHopper enabled, but since we want GreenHopper enabled for all projects, it is the same thing).

This was problematic in GreenHopper 4.4.1 and before, but GreenHopper 5.0 seems to make this problem worse as instead of the pulldown presenting a scrollable list, it now presents a menu which stretches across multiple screens and requires the user to scroll the entire browser window down to see later projects in the list, which is non-intuitive for a user interface.

If GreenHopper were to list the same projects that JIRA does "projects that I have recently accessed", this would be really great.

In some regards, I also wonder why the duplication in functionality is necessary. Since the JIRA "Projects" pulldown already allows project selection, do we really need a second GreenHopper based project selector right underneath? Is it required to dis-ambiguate navigation - user wants to see project page vs GreenHopper planning board for project?
fields.summary: As a user of a JIRA instance with many projects, I want JIRA 4.x style project selection available in the GreenHopper project selector.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Greenhopper tries to display our project name, "Ticker & NLE", in the browser's title bar when on the Agile pages. But, the name is escaped so that it displays incorrectly. From the page source:
{noformat}
<script type="text/javascript">
document.title = "Ticker & NLE - Chart Board - Vizrt JIRA";
</script>
{noformat}
This results in the text "Ticker & NLE" in the title. If I change the code to the following, it displays correctly:
{noformat}
<script type="text/javascript">
document.title = "Ticker & NLE - Chart Board - Vizrt JIRA";
</script>
{noformat}
—

Reproduction steps:

1. Create a project named "This & That".
2. Enable the project in Greenhopper.
3. Open project in Greenhopper's Agile view.

Expected behaviour: Browser tab displays "This & That - Task Board [...]".

Actual behaviour: Browser tab displays "This & That - Task Board [...]".

—

 In Chrome and Firefox.
fields.summary: Greenhopper JavaScript sets browser title incorrectly for ampersand '&'

Currently, all component pulldowns have bullets next to each component name. The downside of this is that you cannot select an item from the pulldown simply by typing the first few letters of the component name (like you normally can with a pulldown).

While the bullets make some amount of sense for versions, as those have a hierarchy, components do not support a hierarchy, and thus the bullets serve no purpose.

They should be removed to allow for easier use of the pulldown.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I Searched a bit, and could not find something quite similar.
This is actually a shared request between Jira / GreenHopper.

The simplicity of how versions are managed currently is quite good, however ones you couple GreenHopper on top of it, we feel it lacks the ability to organizing versions as a "two level tree"...

Problem is that a Version to be released may be produced over several planning cycles (Sprints) and as such the current way seems as a slight missfit.

Weather you wan't to call it a Major/Minor version or something else, I don't know what would make most sense, but if versions was as:

1.0.0.0
 - Sprint 1 / 1.1.0.0
 - Sprint 2 / 1.2.0.0
 - Sprint 3 / 1.3.0.0

2.0.0.0
 - Sprint 4 / 2.1.0.0
 - Sprint 5 / 2.2.0.0
 - Sprint 6 / 2.3.0.0

The sprint items could be used for planning the iterations, while the release notes ect. would be made from the versions.
So in the above example, Sprint 1 to 3 would lead up to the release of version 1, while sprint 4-6 would lead up to version 2...

It's a small improvement, but it would make it fit more into places where Release Cycles are not a direct map to planning cycles.
fields.summary: Major / Minor Versions - Sub versions

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We often use JIRA to help us with release planning using Greenhopper.

We have a list of of issues each with a stories point assigned. We would like to be able to quickly see the culmulative total down the list - so as we reorder things we can see when future releases are likely to fall.

e.g.
JIRA, Description, Points, Culm Points
JIRA-1234, BLAH , 10, 10
JIRA-1234, BLAH , 10, 20
JIRA-1234, BLAH , 10, 30

This should ideally be possible in both the green hopper boards and the issue navigator (to make exporting to excel easy).
fields.summary: For fields like story points it would be useful to have a culmulative field that summed them down the board

fields.description: When using the planning board and printing issues, the output should be paginated so that issues aren't broken across pages. This would also mean that issues would line up if you were to stack pages allowing the printout to be guillotined so that the cards can be stuck on the wall as well.
fields.summary: Print view of greenhopper issues should be paginated

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I'm trying to create different task board contexts (one for Developers, one for QA Testing Engineers).  I would really like to assign task board statuses based per context.  For example in the Developer context I would like to have:
TODO: Open, Assigned, Reopened
In Progress: In Progress
Complete: Ready For Build, Ready for Test, Testing In Progress, Complete

In the Testing context, I would like to have:
TODO: Ready for Test
In Progress: Testing in Progress
Complete: Complete

Notice that the "Ready For Test" status exists in "TODO" (for Testing context) and "Complete" (in Developer context)
fields.summary: Allow context specific task board mappings

fields.description: Some functionality similar to the 'add worklog' which provides the possibility to quickly add a comment to an issue.
fields.summary: As I user, I can add a comment to any issue on any board

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We are using smartboards together with the agile plugin to provide our customers with a simulation 
of a physical scrumboard: 

* The task board is projected on the smartboard. 
* The intention is that users drag tasks from the 'todo' column to the 'in progress' column during the scrum.

The fact is that users have been changing state of individual tasks during the previous day,
and it is therefore more difficult for them to remind what they have been doing.
(especially on a monday).  

It might be handy to be able to flag the tasks that have been modified in some way, so that
during the scrum one can say 'and what happened to this one' ...

Highlighting works partially cause you can 'dim' the issues that didn't change recently, but then
it also dims the containing stories 


Filtering out the non changed issues is not a solution neither cause they must be available to
discuss during the scrum ...
fields.summary: As a user, I can easily identify the issues that have been modified yesterday, to report on it during the scrum

fields.description:
At Setting Up Epics for your Project (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Setting+Up+Epics+for+your+Project), there are two problems:

It's telling us how to make an "Epic" issue type when it already exists. Administration > Issue Types, and it's already there in the GreenHopper Scrum Issue Type Scheme.

Also, under "Configuring your Cards to Use the 'Epic' Custom Field" is:

   1. Log in as a user with the '[Administer Projects' permission|../JIRA/Managing+Project+Permissions] for the project.
   2. Click the 'Tools' menu and click 'Configuration' from the dropdown. The project configuration page will display.

After you log in, the only options in the Tools menu are Copy/Find/Create Dashboards.

Furthermore, in /secure/project/ViewProject.jspa?pid=projectId, there is nothing related to Card Templates nor are there tabs.
fields.summary: Bad documentation in    Setting Up Epics for your Project

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
In the Greenhopper "Task Board" Kanban view, is there anyway to constrain multiple columns such that the sum of the columns has a min/max value? In other words, is there any way for columns to act as "groups" as opposed to "individual columns". For example, I have the following 2 columns:

1. In Development
2. Development Complete

For these two columns as a "group", I would like to set a minimum of 2 and a maximum of 10. In other words, the following are valid:

1. In Development = 0; Development Complete = 10
2. In Development = 10; Development Complete = 0
3. In Development = 5; Development Complete = 5
4. In Development = 1; Development Complete = 1
5. In Development = 2; Development Complete = 0
6. In Development = 0; Development Complete = 2

As far as I know, columns only act independently of each other (i.e., I could set a minimum of 1 and maximum of 5 for both columns individually).
fields.summary: Group multiple Task Board columns for busted column contraints (max/min)

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I'm in the middle of developing some licensed plugins, for which I'm using the TrueLicense libraries.  GreenHopper is packing TrueLicense inside its JAR, I can understand packing it makes deployment easier but its TBH not forward thinking in terms of playing nice with other plugins.

Annoyingly there appears to be a method signature difference between the last actual release of TrueLicense/TrueXml by the author (v 1.2.9) and what is packed in GreenHopper, so whether its an old version, or a modified version, its incompatible with the current release - and therefore my plugin.

*If* there are code changes to make it 'specific' to GH, could I ask that it be repackaged out of the namespace of TrueLicense so as not to 'own' that namespace?

How about splitting out the TrueLicense libraries into their own plugin, could even be bundled with Jira?
fields.summary: Please unpack the TrueLicense packages from GreenHopper, its not exactly in the spirit of reuse!

    * after the chart loads, go to the taskboard
    * this will bring up the taskboard, but you will not get a stack trace because there are no tasks
    * change the context to a good context, or delete if you are the create user.

Can this be a feature request that a jira administrator is able to delete contexts in greenhopper via some admin screen OR can the application catch the exception and show an empty task board with 'bad context' message to the user?

fields.description:
We have observed that with Greenhopper installed (and presumably when it is enabled for a given project) that subtasks which are created without specifying a fix version (namely, from within the standard Jira 4.0.x interface options) will inherit *every* fixVersion from their parent, even versions which have been archived.

This allows the content of the archived versions to be changed after they have been archived and interferes with the integrity of historical data.

So, given the following hierarchical version relationship within Greenhopper...
{noformat}
Release Goal
|-- Release Backlog
`-- Release Commitment
    `-- Sprint
        `-- Sprint Plan (Archived)
{noformat}

...we may have a number of issues and subtasks which were Archived as part of the "Sprint Plan" version (to provide a baseline for future comparison). Additional Sprint work takes place in the "Sprint" version. If additional subtasks for one of the planned issues are created either within a Greenhopper version board focusing on the Sprint version or from within a Jira screen explicitly specifying the "Sprint" fix version, then the subtask is created as desired, with the "Release Goal", "Release Commitment" and "Sprint" versions, but without the archived "Sprint Plan" version. 

In fact, because the "Sprint Plan" version has been archived, it cannot be assigned to a new subtask through conventional means. 

However, if the subtask is created through the Jira interface and a version is not assigned at creation time, every fixVersion from the parent is duplicated in the subtask. The workaround for a subtask in this condition is laborious as it involves unarchiving the version, editing the subtask to remove the version which the listener added in error and rearchiving the version.

Note that all that is necessary for this to take place is to have Greenhopper installed on the system. It will occur even if the project is not associated with Greenhopper and if all of the configurable listeners are disabled. I conclude from this that the process which is setting these versions is a core listener associated with Greenhopper.
fields.summary: Archived versions should not be included when fix versions are propagated (via listener?) to new subtasks

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When using Greenhopper/Jira for full-fledged project management, there are generally a number of "time buckets" that are project-wide and don't necessarily represent discrete tasks or work items. For example, we may have a Project Management component, with tasks for Daily Scrum, Scheduling, Client meetings, etc. We generally don't chop these up by iteration and put them on the task board. So to find them, one must switch to the planning board, view by component, then find the bucket you want.

It would be great if we could have a way to quickly access project-wide tasks, mainly for rapid time entry. Maybe the forums concept of a "pinned" post, where the issue always appears in certain views, or the concept of a "dock" that could be loaded with issues. Simpler would be a project-wide dock, more complex would be user-specific ones.

BAsically the user story is "as a project team member I want to be able to easily log time against any of a number of project-wide tasks."

Perhaps this can be accomplished using out of the box features and I just haven't been creative enough yet ...
fields.summary: "pinned" issues (or other means of quick access)

fields.description: In more complex development flow including several stakeholders/roles (developers, component owners, testers, release managers, ...) every role needs to see just columns it is interested in (eg. testers are interested in DONE and TESTINg columns). Currently the user can customize the view enabling and disabling certain columns. But it is slow and uncomfortable when you have more than one role and does not want to have all the columns visible on a page all the time (eg. because of lack of space on your display). The "perspective" will be definition of Task Board View - which columns are enabl ed or disabled, so you can quickly switch the view eg. from tester's role to release manager's role to see proper columns the role is intrested in.
fields.summary: Task Board Views like "perspectives"

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Problem:
Greenhopper's burn down chart treats the entire project as a single engineering unit. In reality, most modern systems are composed of several components, each of which has its own unique technology, resources and velocity.
 
Request: 
allow admins to configure burn down chart by component. If component is chosen, the burn down chart will calculate the backlog for that component based on total number of story points. Then, as stories are scheduled to sprints, calculate velocity and burn down rate for each component. Lastly, aggregate all component burn down charts into a integrated chart which displays component burn down within the larger project's burn down.
 
Benefit: 
allows team leads for each component to adjust resources and balance load so that product development proceeds at a unified rate.
fields.summary: Configure burn down chart by component

fields.description:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. open JIRA
2. open the Task Board
3. set Views to Outline and List 
4. drag a task at the bottom of the screen to a new status

Observed:
The screen position jumps so the first task under the story to which the moved task belongs is at the top of the page. The story itself is off the page. This is very disruptive to meeting flow as we update task status and have to chase the stories all over the board. 

Expected:
Dragging a task to a new status should not change screen position.

*Steps to replicate the problem*:
1. Go to the task board using Internet Explorer 8. 
2. Make sure it is a task board with tasks in the TO DO or IN PROGRESS column (because you'll need to try dragging them later). 
3. Also make sure that Auto Refresh is not on. 
4. Now... don't do anything in Jira for an hour (or whatever your timeout period is). 
5. After an hour, drag a task to another column and watch it spin forever. 
6. When you get tired, hit 'reload' and you'll see that you're not logged in anymore.

fields.description:
The current statement in the [GH Upgrade guide|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/GreenHopper+Installation+and+Upgrade+Guide] is:
bq. Please note, GreenHopper does not add or alter JIRA tables or columns, i.e. adding or removing GreenHopper from your installed plugins will not cause any collateral damage to your JIRA data.

I propose a change to something like:

bq. Please note, GreenHopper does not add or alter JIRA tables or columns that will affect JIRA if GreenHopper is removed. GreenHopper does add its own tables and columns to the JIRA database and therefore may write new tables or columns to the JIRA database during GreenHopper installation and upgrade.
fields.summary: Clarify comment on Install doc

fields.description:
Since upgrading to the v4.3 version, the team using Greenhopper has seen a noticeable decrease in performance. Although there is not enough of an issue to change our patterns at this time, it is starting to be enough of an issue that we might start thinking of going back to an older version where performance was better. 

Here are some stats that might be helpful.
* About 6 - 10 people that are actively using it per project
* We run 2 - 3 projects at a time
* Between 50 (smaller projects) and 200 (larger projects) issues within a version
* Most projects have between 5 - 15 versions open at any one time depending on projects (we break down backlogs, sprints, iterations, etc)
* Greenhopper Version 4.3
* We are all very active within the plug-in. Including stand-ups, backlog grooming, estimation sessions, & updating work through-out the day.
fields.summary: Performance has decreased on planning/tasks board since upgrading to v4.3 of Greenhopper

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The agile gadget extends the end date of the release to the date of the *master* release. This makes the Agile gadget unusable for iteration tracking.

1) What worked:
We had in project "X" versions:
* "0.1.0 Sprint 2" with start date 1 end date 7
* "0.1.0 Sprint 3" with start date 8 end date 15
* "2.0.0 Sprint 4" with start date 16 end date 23

When working in "Sprint 2", we set up an issue search filter:
  project = X AND fixVersion = "0.1.0 Sprint 2" ORDER BY priority DESC

When displaying the Agile Gadget on the dashboard, we could use this filter, and the burndown would have an end date of date 7. This is as it is.

2) What did not work:
We discovered the "Master" version feature of Greenhopper, so we changed the version structure to be:
* "0.1.0" with end date 15
  * "Sprint 2" with start date 1 and end date 7 having "0.1.0" as Master.
  * "Sprint 3" with start date 8 and end date 15 having "0.1.0" as Master.
* "2.0.0"
  * Sprint 4" with start date 16 and end date 23 having "2.0.0" as Master.

We changed the issue search filter to be:
   project = X AND fixVersion = "Sprint 2" ORDER BY priority DESC
and also verified that we retrieved the same number and the same issues as in the working example above.

Now the problem is, that when we have the Agile Gadget configured to use the search filter for "Sprint 2", the graph is changed to have an end date of 15. This is an error.

I have included screenshots:
greenhopper-example-1.png is the working example.
greenhopper-example-2.png is the non-working example.
fields.summary: The Agile Gadget uses wrong end date when setting up a version to have a Master Version
